user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_for_upgrade:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_for_upgrade (MHD_UpgradeHandler upgrade_handler,
                                 void *upgrade_handler_cls)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

  if (NULL == upgrade_handler)
    return NULL; /* invalid request */
  response = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response));
  if (NULL == response)
    return NULL;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  if (! MHD_mutex_init_ (&response->mutex))
  {
    free (response);
    return NULL;
  }
#endif
  response->upgrade_handler = upgrade_handler;
  response->upgrade_handler_cls = upgrade_handler_cls;
  response->total_size = 0;
  response->reference_count = 1;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION,
                               "Upgrade"))
  {
    MHD_destroy_response (response);
    return NULL;
  }
  return response;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_create_response_for_upgrade:
typedef void
(*MHD_UpgradeHandler)(void *cls,
                      struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      void *req_cls,
                      const char *extra_in,
                      size_t extra_in_size,
                      MHD_socket sock,
                      struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in MHD_create_response_for_upgrade modifies a function parameter. The two parameters are: (1) upgrade_handler (function pointer) and (2) upgrade_handler_cls (void *). Both are only read and their values are copied into members of the newly allocated response object (response->upgrade_handler and response->upgrade_handler_cls). There are no assignments to the parameter variables themselves, no increment/decrement or other modifying operators applied to them, and their addresses are not taken and passed to other functions that could modify them. All other operations (memory allocation, mutex init, setting response fields, calling MHD_add_response_header) operate on the local response object or local temporaries, not on the parameter variables. Therefore there are no code fragments that require investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
